abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory, but
            sustainability is unlikely because, although the project
            contributed to cost-effective development of tree crops at
            national economic levels, concerns about small-holder tree
            crop development prevail, particularly considering the
            current rapid move towards decentralization of Government
            interventions. A range of lessons address both positive and
            negative aspects. While the establishment of successful tree
            crop nurseries, and perennial inter-crops, proved
            appropriate and resilient technical models, favorable to the
            environment, instances of faulty site selection with respect
            to soils and climate, and inappropriate selection of
            varieties or clones have occurred, aggravated by the failure
            to ensure timely provision of planting material, or vital
            agro-inputs. Regarding institutional aspects, effective
            project management ensured the quality of physical
            achievements, and the development of cohesive farmers'
            groups, but, following completion of the project, the
            utilization of a number of local staff, and extension
            workers is questioned, since remuneration lies on
            Government's will. Although financing, and cost
            recovery showed positive aspects given the accessibility to
            credit by small-holders, credit collection has become
            counter-productive, and, arbitrary cut-off points induce
            credit evasion. Further lessons address land titling, and
            extension/training aspects.
